t: Ecclesiastes 10
The Burden of Folly
Dead*pn flies make a perfumer’s oil ferment and stink; so*ln a little folly outweighs wisdom and honor.
A*ln wise person’s heart goes to the right, but*ln a fool’s heart to the left.
Even*ln when the fool walks along the road, his heart lacks sense, and*ln he shows everyone he is a fool.
If*ln the ruler’s anger rises against you, don’t leave your post, for*ln calmness puts great offenses to rest.
There*p is an evil I have seen under the sun, an error proceeding from the presence of the ruler:
The*pn fool is appointed to great heights, but*ln the rich remain in lowly positions.
I*ln have seen slaves on horses, but*ln princes walking on the ground like slaves.
The*pn one who digs a pit may fall into it, and*ln the one who breaks through a wall may be bitten by a snake.
The*ln one who quarries stones may be hurt by them; the*ln one who splits logs may be endangered by them.
If*ln the ax is dull, and one does not sharpen its edge, then*ln one must exert more strength; however,*ln the advantage of wisdom is that it brings success.
If*ln the snake bites before it is charmed, then*ln there is no advantage for the charmer.
The*ln words from the mouth of a wise person are gracious, but*ln the lips of a fool consume him.
The*ln beginning of the words from his mouth is folly, but*ln the end of his speaking is evil madness;
yet*ln the fool multiplies words. No*ln one knows what will happen, and*ln who can tell anyone what will happen after him?
The*ln struggles of fools weary them, for*ln they don’t know how to go to the city.
Woe*ln to you, land, when your king is a youth and*ln your princes feast in the morning.
Blessed*ln are you, land, when your king is a son of nobles and*ln your princes feast at the proper time — for*ln strength and not for drunkenness.
Because*ln of laziness the roof caves in, and*ln because of negligent hands the house leaks.
A*ln feast is prepared for laughter, and*ln wine makes life happy, and*ln money is the answer for everything.
Do*ln not curse the king even in your thoughts, and*ln do not curse a rich person even in your bedroom, for*ln a bird of the sky may carry the message, and*ln a winged creature may report the matter.
